docs.snippet: The directors of the Gillette Company, the razor-blade giant based in Boston, have appointed Collman M. Mockler Jr. as president and chief operating officer. His appointment, announced yesterday, ended several weeks of speculation over the successor...
docs.lead_paragraph: The directors of the Gillette Company, the razor-blade giant based in Boston, have appointed Collman M. Mockler Jr. as president and chief operating officer. His appointment, announced yesterday, ended several weeks of speculation over the successor to Edward Gelsthorpe, who unexpectedly resigned as president three weeks ago after serving in that post for less than 14 months.
docs.abstract: Colman M Mockler Jr apptd pres and chief operating officer of Gillette Co, succeeding Edward Gelsthorpe (S)

headline.main: President Appointed at Gillette; People and Business

docs.snippet: Churchmen of 150 countries represented at the World Evangelization Congress here decided today not to form a permanent organization in opposition to the World Council of Churches.
docs.lead_paragraph: Churchmen of 150 countries represented at the World Evangelization Congress here decided today not to form a permanent organization in opposition to the World Council of Churches.
docs.abstract: Churchmen of 150 countries represented at World Evangelization Cong decide not to form permanent orgn in opposition to World Council of Chs; plans 30-member 'continuation com' that will 'maintain and extend mutual encouragement and fellowship'; participants maintain that certain Christian groups, without mentioning World Council of Chs, tend to overemphasize econ and soc problems (M)

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

headline.main: Foreign Exchange; Money New Bond Issues

docs.snippet: From drought-besieged Africa to the jittery Chicago grain market, from worried Government offices in Washington to the partly-filled granaries of teeming India, Drought and hunger In Africa and Asia are unfamiliar to Americans accustomed to...
docs.lead_paragraph: From drought-besieged Africa to the jittery Chicago grain market, from worried Government offices in Washington to the partly-filled granaries of teeming India, Drought and hunger In Africa and Asia are unfamiliar to Americans accustomed to wellstocked supermarkets, and ample crops of grains have long produced surpluses that helped feed much of the world. Now, a world food crisis finds experts agreeing that American agriculture cannot forever meet developing deficits.
docs.abstract: NY Times survey on growing threat of world food crisis notes world population is expanding by larger numbers each yr, especially in poor countries that are most susceptible to famine; notes world population increased by 76-million in '73 (M)

headline.main: Experts Ask Action to A void Millions of Deaths in Food Crisis; A Different Situation Sooner Than Expected Experts Not Optimistic Experts Call for Action in Food Crisis Below the Minimum New Credit Sought Realistic Solution

docs.snippet: Cowboys of the world - beef seems to be taking a modest place next to oil as one of the latest sources of international trouble, and like oil, it cuts across all other divisions. Meat processing at Rungis, major food market in Paris. It has been...
docs.lead_paragraph: Cowboys of the world - beef seems to be taking a modest place next to oil as one of the latest sources of international trouble, and like oil, it cuts across all other divisions. Meat processing at Rungis, major food market in Paris. It has been reported that the Soviet Union was buying Western European beef well below the world price.

headline.main: Beef Joins Oil as Source Of World's Latest Woe; Makes the Mouth Water' Italy a Big Customer
